'''George Kingsley Zipf''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|z|ɪ|f}};<ref>{{citation|title=A Pocket Guide to Risk Mathematics: Key Concepts Every Auditor Should Know|first=Matthew|last=Leitch|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=2010|isbn=9780470971468|page=62|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=f8GrzlnMSm8C&pg=PA62}}.</ref> 1902–1950), was an [[United States|American]] [[linguistics|linguist]] and [[philologist]] who studied [[statistics|statistical]] occurrences in different [[language]]s.<ref name="crimson">{{citation|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1950/9/27/zipf-dies-after-3-month/|title=Zipf Dies After 3 - Month Illness|newspaper=[[The Harvard Crimson]]|date=September 27, 1950}}.</ref>

Zipf earned his bachelors, masters, and doctoral degrees from [[Harvard University]], although he also studied at the [[University of Bonn]] and the [[University of Berlin]].<ref name="crimson"/>
He was Chairman of the German Department and University Lecturer (meaning he could teach any subject he chose) at [[Harvard University]].<ref name="crimson"/> He worked with [[Chinese language|Chinese]] and [[demographics]], and much of his effort can explain properties of the [[Internet]], distribution of income within nations, and many other collections of data.<ref>{{citation|title=Theory of Zipf's Law and Beyond|volume=632|series=Lecture notes in economics and mathematical systems|first1=A. I.|last1=Saichev|first2=Yannick|last2=Malevergne|first3=Didier|last3=Sornette|publisher=Springer|year=2009|isbn=9783642029462|page=1|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=orSSCf69ZhMC&pg=PA1}}.</ref>

==Zipf's law==
{{Main|Zipf's law}}
George Kingsley Zipf is the [[eponym]] of [[Zipf's law]], which states that while only a few words are used very often, many or most are used rarely,

:<math>P_n \sim 1/n^a</math>

where ''P<sub>n</sub>'' is the frequency of a word ranked ''n''<sup>th</sup> and the exponent ''a'' is almost 1.  This means that the second item occurs approximately 1/2 as often as the first, and the third item 1/3 as often as the first, and so on. Zipf's discovery of this law in 1935 was one of the first academic studies of [[word frequency]].<ref>{{citation|title=Word Frequency Distributions|volume=18|series=Text, Speech and Language Technology|first=R. Harald|last=Baayen|publisher=Springer|year=2002|isbn=9781402009273|page=13|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=fzkQPKoFEb0C&pg=PA1}}.</ref>

Although he originally intended it as a model for linguistics, Zipf later generalized his law to other disciplines. In particular, he observed that the rank vs. frequency distribution of individual incomes in a unified nation approximates this law, and in his 1941 book, "National Unity and Disunity" he theorized that breaks in this "normal curve of income distribution" portend social pressure for change or [[revolution]].
